title: Driving Distance
text:
# A tibble: 1 × 2
   .row  odds
  <int> <dbl>
1     1 0.063


# A tibble: 1 × 2
   .row  odds
  <int> <dbl>
1     1 0.856



So 6% of the time at tournaments PGA players could drive over 300 yards on average. However, 86% of the time at tournament, they could drive it over 280 yards on average. Different factors can disrupt this, such as the difficulty of the course making it trickier to drive longer. However, in general, we see that gaining those extra 20 yards is extremely difficult.

title: Model
text:
I used the same model for all graphs, but a different formula for yardage.
I used a Gaussian Predictive Model (GPM) to calculate the average score to par, driving distance, and course yardage based on data from 91 PGA golf courses.
For the first two graphs -
The model follows the formula:
\[
y_i = \mu + \epsilon_i
\]
Where:

yi is the average score or driving distance of course i.
\(\mu\) is the average score or driving distance across all PGA courses.
The error term i, the difference between the observed and predicted value, follows a normal distribution with mean 0 which can be written as:

\[
\epsilon_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2)
\]  
For the last graph, the model follows the formula
\[
score_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot yardage_i + \epsilon_i
\] Where:

\(\beta_0\) is the intercept term
\(\beta_1\) is the coefficient for the yardage
yardagei is the yardage for the i-th observation
\(\epsilon_i\), the error term, is difference between the observed and predicted value, follows a normal distribution with mean 0 which can be written as:

\[
\epsilon_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2)
\]
Details about model used-


 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = identity 
Formula: adj_score_to_par ~ 1 
   Data: first_model (Number of observations: 91) 
  Draws: 4 chains, each with iter = 2000; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup draws = 4000

Regression Coefficients:
          Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS
Intercept    -0.01      0.17    -0.33     0.32 1.00     3051     2486

Further Distributional Parameters:
      Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS
sigma     1.55      0.12     1.35     1.80 1.00     3195     2271

Draws were sampled using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Bulk_ESS
and Tail_ESS are effective sample size measures, and Rhat is the potential
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).

title: About
text:
Hi! My name is Zephan Shivam, and I’m a middle schooler from Austin, Texas.
You can see this project and much more at my github, https://github.com/PythonGoaler. If you want to contact me directly, you can contact me at my email, fearlessfan03 @ gmail dot com.
I made this project because I’m passionate about golf and wanted to explore it more. If you want to see details of my various projcets, here is my github repo - https://github.com/PythonGoaler
This project was created as a part of Kane’s Data Science Bootcamp
